sn42.1:1.2: Then the chief named Fury went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
sn42.1:1.3: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some people are regarded as furious,
sn42.1:1.4: while others are regarded as sweet-natured?”
sn42.1:1.5: “Take someone who hasn’t given up greed.
sn42.1:1.6: So they get annoyed by others, and they show it.
sn42.1:1.9: So they get annoyed by others, and they show it.
sn42.1:1.12: So they get annoyed by others, and they show it.
sn42.1:1.14: This is the cause, this is the reason why some people are regarded as furious.
sn42.1:2.1: But take someone who has given up greed.
sn42.1:2.2: So they don’t get annoyed by others, and don’t show it.
sn42.1:2.5: So they don’t get annoyed by others, and don’t show it.
sn42.1:2.8: So they don’t get annoyed by others, and don’t show it.
sn42.1:2.10: This is the cause, this is the reason why some people are regarded as sweet-natured.”
sn42.1:3.1: When he said this, the chief named Fury said to the Buddha,
sn42.1:3.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
sn42.1:3.4: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
sn42.1:3.5: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
